titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Guerrilla Girls Archive
1985-2010
MSS 274
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rosemary K. J. Davis, 2010.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-04-02T17:06-0400

physdesc.extent: (5 record cartons, 3 oversize boxes, 1 document case)

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Guerrilla Girls emerged onto the scene in 1985, vocally and visually protesting perceived inequities in the art world. Using statistics-based, text-centric posters, the group accused art institutions and art critics who failed to provide women and minorities representation.

In the late nineties, the Guerrilla Girls entered a phase during which some of its founding members split apart from the group. Disagreements over focus, financial dealings, and the future of the collective's mission lead to the formation of three separate groups, all three of which still function. Today, the GuerrillaGirlsBroadBand, Inc., Guerrilla Girls On Tour, Inc. (the Theatre Girls), and Guerrilla Girls, Inc all seek to further the original feminist idealogies of the collective.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1985, the Guerrilla Girls are a feminist art collective who focused on issues of gender and racial inequity in the art world, specifically the under-representation of women and minorities in museum and gallery exhibitions. Through posters and protests, the Guerrilla Girls worked to bring attention to the lack of equality in traditional art establishments. This collection includes posters, financial and legal documents, correspondence, and ephemera that span the existence of the collective and shed light on its transition from upstart activist group to a trio of organizations, each with their own feminist focus.
The collection is organized into seven series.

Series I. Administrative Records: consists of correspondence, financial records, invoices, and documentation related to the business dealings of the Guerrilla Girls in all their incarnations. The records include details about logistics of gigs, correspondence pertaining to the "break-up" of the group, and information about the donation of their archival holdings.

blockquote.p:
Subseries A. Guerrilla Girls Notes, Correspondence, and Clippings
Subseries B. GuerrillaGirlsBroadBand Notes and Correspondence
Subseries C. Financial Documentation and Accounting Records
Subseries D. Archive Sale Documentation and Correspondence

scopecontent.p: Series II. Legal Records and Related Correspondence: contains official legal documents pertaining to a lawsuit instigated by two original members of the Guerrilla Girls against the other members of the group. Official depositions and motions, along with formal and informal correspondence are included.

blockquote.p:
Subseries A. Legal Documents and Proceedings
Subseries B. Miscellaneous Legal Correspondence and Research Notes

scopecontent.p: Series III. Lectures, Performances, and Exhibitions: comprises correspondence related to performances and appearances by members of the Guerrilla Girls in all their incarnations. Postcards, posters, press mentions, official catalogs, and research notes are also included.

blockquote.p:
Subseries A. Gig Notes, Correspondence, and Clippings
Subseries B. Related Catalogs and Publications

scopecontent.p: Series IV. Research and Notes: contains correspondence, notes, articles, and clippings used to develop projects including books, performances, and artworks.

blockquote.p:
Subseries A. Guerrilla Girls Project Notes
Subseries B. Miscellaneous Research and Clippings

scopecontent.p: Series V. Posters and Graphic Works 1985-2010: includes original artistic output from the Guerrilla Girls including posters, graphic works, and objects.

blockquote.p:
Subseries A. Posters
Subseries B. Postcards, Stickers, and Miscellaneous Graphic Works
Subseries C. Dimensional Works and Ephemera

scopecontent.p: Series VI. Publications 1985-1998: comprises works authored and compiled by the Guerrilla Girls, along with annotated proofs and drafts.

blockquote.p:
Subseries A. Publications
Subseries B. Proofs and Notes

scopecontent.p: Series VII. Media: contains research materials, administrative records and legal documentation.
Subseries A. Originals The Oversize section--Boxes 6, 7, and 8--includes materials from: Series III/Subseries A, Series V/Subseries A, B, and C, Series VI/Subseries A and B.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Primarily, collection materials are arranged chronologically within each series. Undated materials are generally found at the end of each Series or Subseries. Realia, video and audio media have been separated out into a separate subseries to facilitate usage. Each object and media element have then been assigned unique identification numbers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Guerrilla Girls Archive; MSS 274; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.
